newsitem.title: INDONESIA: Jakarta call money traded at 14.0/15.0 percent.
newsitem.headline: Jakarta call money traded at 14.0/15.0 percent.

text.p: Jakarta call money was traded at 14.0/15.0 percent on Monday morning, dealers said.
The central bank money policy was neutral on Monday.
Dealers said the carry-forward effect from last Friday was still felt in the market as some banks moved to cover their shortages early on fear of a possible repeat.
Overnight money soared to a high of 45 percent before settling at 40 percent late on Friday. Dealers said the jump was technical and was not due to fundamental changes.
One European bank dealer said overnight rates' jump last Friday seemed to unsettle some small banks, which boosted their rupiah reserves and kept overnight money at 14.5 percent.
Longer-term rates were up, with one-week money traded at 14.00/14.25 and one-month at 13.50/13.75 percent, respectively.
One local bank dealer said rates should stabilise further because some banks had misread the market last Friday.
The central bank lowered its six-month bilateral papers (SBIs) by 25 basis points to 11.25 percent on Monday.

The central bank offered overnight SBIs at five percent, seven-day at seven percent, two-week at 8.25 percent, one-month at 10.25 percent, three at 10.75 percent, six at 11.25 percent and 12-month at 12.0 percent.
Bond dealers said focus was still on the primary market, with volume on the secondary market remaining thin.
The average overnight interbank rate on Friday was 15.93 percent, compared with 10.79 percent on Thursday.
